text.p: These are the highlights of the main Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro newspapers this morning.
-- AGREEMENT ON SAO PAULO'S DEBTS OUT TODAY
Sao Paulo state governor Mario Covas and Finance Minister Pedro Malan will sign today a debt refinancing deal for Sao Paulo state, including debts owed to state bank Banespa.

Speaking before a special lower house committee looking into the re-election amendment, Sao Paulo mayor and hopeful presidential candidate Paulo Maluf criticized the current government, backed the re-election only for the successor of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso and proposed a plebiscite on the issue.
-- CENTRAL BANK EYES CLOSELY BRAZIL'S RATES

The Central Bank's Monetary Policy Commitee (Copom) is likely to set today the Basic Interest Rate of the Central Bank (TBC) for December. But the market should not expect a TBC much lower than November's 1.78 percent rate because some Central Bank officials are concerned about the country's economic activity.
Presidents Fernando Henrique Cardoso and Nelson Mandela announced plans to expand trade relations between Brazil and South Africa during a meeting in which four agreements were signed.
After the Real Plan, 13 million of low-income Brazilians went shopping ignoring interest rates
-- USP FINDS NEW TREATMENT FOR CANCER
A researcher from Sao Paulo University (USP) has developed a technique which improves treatment for cancer.
-- Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
